values:
Once again I need to talk about the importance of masks and costume.  I can't overstate how important they are.  If I filled up a book with just the sentence "masks and costume are incredibly important" it still wouldn't be overstating it.

Costume is the very first thing that a person sees when they look at you, and they will be judging you based on that costume.  This is subconscious reaction here, they don't even really know they are doing it; if asked they would probably give a knee-jerk response of "no!  I don't do that!" even as they mentally admitted to themselves that they had.

To leverage that subconscious response, you must know what your audience will be drawn to.  I'll use myself for an example here, because I just wore a carefully chosen costume.

First, I start with the desired perception I want to instill.  In this case it was meeting a group of dominant males and females; with one exception, they had never met me before.  I wanted to give the impression of power, confidence, and attractiveness.  I wanted to be perceived as being better than them, but not ostentatiously so.  First piece: a pair of black jeans that fit me closely, but were not 'skinny jeans'.  I wanted to emphasize that I was in good shape; the black jeans were not 'business dress', but were not so casual that I seemed to be dressing down.  Helping to dress up the jeans was a belt of black elephant leather; elephant leather has a unique rough texture to it that I very much like.

Second piece was a Thomas Pink cotton French cuff dress shirt in a royal purple herringbone twill.  The cotton twill gave texture to the shirt, emphasizing the lushness of the Thomas Pink material; again making it not seem like 'business dress', but being offset by the French cuffs (with square gold cuff links in a checkerboard pattern.)  The royal purple color was carefully chosen for several reasons; again to conflict with a 'business dress' appearance, but also because women, as a whole, love the color purple.  Purple is also connected with the mystical, the spiritual and death itself; all facets of power.

I then wore black and white saddle shoes; the white is polished and smooth, but the black is of shark skin which has a wonderful texture.  Saddle shoes are not much worn today, add the black and white contrast to the rest of the outfit and they become an obvious affectation.  At least, it's obvious to me; I am disheartened by how much obvious subcontext is only seemingly obvious to me.

The compliments on my outfit came immediately and they kept coming throughout the night.  Likewise comments on "that I had obviously lost weight", "looked great", and "looked younger" were also given.  I also noticed that the moment I began to offer a comment, I immediately became the focus of the conversation, with everyone going out of their way to cede the control of the discussion to me.

There is a line from an old Henry Fonda spaghetti western called "My Name Is Nobody".  The title character, Nobody, is a young up-and-coming snot nosed wannabe who trails after the old celebrity gunslinger played by Henry Fonda (who wants nothing so much as to peacefully retire somewhere far away from The Old West.)  At one point in the movie Henry Fonda looks at Nobody , whose rhinestone and tin studded clothing has him shining in the noon-day sun.  Henry Fonda says disgustedly, "Son, I've seen the front door to whore houses that didn't shine as much as you do."   Nobody replies, "Well, I like people to see me."

You don't need to be as blatant as wearing rhinestones to grab a persons attention; usually it's playing to the well established rules of costume that have the greatest effect.  Remember, if you want people to believe you are a cop, you only need to wear a cops uniform.

Do you think wolves are happy when they are alone? The 'lone wolf' has become a trope to humanity, but what does it mean to the wolf? Does a lone wolf want to be a lone wolf? The wolves don't share their thoughts with us, so we will never know, but I can make educated guesses and filter them through my own eyes. There is power in the pack. A group of wolves can more effectively gather food which means better chances at survival. Having a pack means a better genetic database to draw from which translates to better chances of healthier pups and genetic diversity. Having a pack allows a better chance for survival of a non-prime specimen. There is evidence that the power of the pack is multiplicative rather than additive. So why would a wolf ever leave the pack? We know they do. If there a huge advantages to being in a pack, what possible advantages could there be in being a lone wolf? In the pack, the prime advantages go to the alphas. If a beta wolf finds it difficult to achieve advancement, it might be more advantageous to leave and find a different pack where their chances are better. If a wolf is having to fight to attain a share in food or reproductive rights at every turn, then it might actually have an easier time leaving the high levels of competition in the pack for a solitary existence. The lone wolf rarely remains a lone wolf for long however. Humans are more closely related to the wolf than they like to think.

You know what the best way to lie is?  It's not to be really good with your lies.  It isn't being a good actor, having a great memory, or a particularly good manner with people, although all of those things help.

The best way of lying is to always tell the truth, but to tell the truth in such a way that what your listener believes is the truth is wrong.  It does mean that you have to be very careful about exactly how you tell the truth...but I didn't say this was the easiest way of lying.

And only tell just as much of the truth as you absolutely need to; too much truth doesn't leave as much ambiguity.

I have a watershed moment rapidly approaching. Add into that the fact that I am trying to do a thing that I've never done before, which puts me in a totally new and unexplored environment, and I feel I'm floundering in a dark and unknowable sea. The worst part is that I really haven't decided upon what my goal is with all of this. It's a situation rife with potential and I'm placing that potential firmly in the hands of fate; I'm saying, "I've never done this before, but I'm trying to do it now, and I am willing to see where this all takes me. These next two months will determine the course of the rest of my life and I fully accept the risks I'm taking. Here Fate, show me whether I'm doing the right thing or the wrong thing; show me if these risks pay off or if how I've always gone about things was the right way of doing things." It's scary and risky, but I realize that I have very little to lose. My pride and sense of self won't be harmed by this; I have far too much confidence in my self for any failure to really break me. Not to say that I won't torture myself should this not pay off, simply that I know that the difference between taking this risk and not taking this risk are comparatively minor. It's the payoff that changes everything. It's sort of like deciding to play the lotto or not; you know that if you don't play you are guaranteed to not win, and that if you do play the lotto your chances are infinitesimal. Either way the worst that happens is you only lose a dollar. But if you do win... If I win, what do I get? Soooooo many problems. It'll make my life incredibly more complex. It won't actually solve anything. Yet... I've never done this before, never tried this before. The fact that I am actually trying is the triumph. I'm not expecting to win; actually, I'm expecting to lose. I don't actually see how I could win. Does the dog actually expect to catch the squirrel when it chases it? It wants to, and it'll probably figure out to do if it does catch it, but most dogs go through their lives never even getting close. The lesson is to enjoy the chase and learn to be content with that alone. The goal shouldn't be winning itself, but that you are trying to win. The anticipation of a thing is as good, or better, than the thing itself.

Plans are what you make while you are waiting for life to happen.

Then life happens, completely ignoring all the careful plans you've laid out, instead bulldozing them under as it drags you down the path it chose without consulting you.

How long ago did I learn that lesson?  When I was 7?  Maybe age 9 at the latest?

The one way that you can absolutely guarantee that something won't happen is to imagine it in you head, plot out the course of the events, and make plans for what you will do in that eternity.  Fate will gladly choose to prove you wrong and make all your plans worthless.

So, never imagine things going right, things working out for you, winning the lottery, achieving the goals you want.  Only imagine the bad things happenning.  Imagine the failure, imagine things going wrong and losing all that you hold precious.

Now sit in a corner and try not to imagine a red rhinoceros.

You get extra points if you know to what that was a reference.  No one has ever been able to get the extra points for actually doing it.

Have you ever tried to analyze what it is about music that you like?  I mean, really, why you like a particular song?

I know that I like music that expresses raw emotion.  I know that I like songs written in a minor key.  I know that I like layered and syncopated beats.  But simply coming up with a list of stuff I like isn't enough for me. I've taken it further; if there is one thing that I do best, it's continue to analyze things over and over again.

A song should have 4 movements.  The first movement is the introduction; it begins simple and establishes the rhythm and baseline for the song.  As the first movement progresses, the song adds layer upon layer of complexity to the original beginning.  The second movement takes that complexity and multilayered nature of the harmonies and then experiments with variations.  The third movement kicks in with a drop of all the layers from the musical instruments and becomes sparse allowing the singers to showcase their voices (actual breakbeats are common at the beginning and end of this movement).  The fourth movement then returns all the layers and complexity from the second movement, and the song finishes in a wonderful crescendo.

Examples:  Daft Punk "Harder Better Faster Stronger", Linkin Park "When They Come For Me", Yellow Ostrich "Whale"

Those three songs are perfect illustrations.

I do like songs that don't perfectly follow the pattern, but it's startling just how much I do like this pattern.  Songs that fit this pattern seem to have a perfect balance about them, a completeness that I find very satisfying.

Years ago, I was given a sealed letter by a girl I knew. There was no explanation, just "this if for you." I'm not certain I can explain how much I loved that sealed envelope. That envelope was full of...potential. Full of mystery. I could tell that my name on the front of the letter had been written by a woman, perhaps even the woman who had given me the letter. But what the letter inside said I couldn't know, wouldn't know until I opened the envelope. And I didn't want to open that letter. As long as that letter was unopened it could be anything, say anything. Would it be a profession of love or a proclamation of hate? I held that letter for hours, carried it with me unopened. It was an ember in my pocket, burning me with it's mystery and it's potential. And I loved that burn, that pain. Some things are so easy to explain with math, but I realize that most people don't think that way. For those who do, it was simply that I didn't want to collapse it's wave-function. For those who don't, I didn't want to reduce what could be almost anything down to one specific thing that was guaranteed to be less wonderful than the potential it represented in my imagination. When it comes right down to it, I love potential more than I love knowing. I guess that's why I like puzzles so much; I enjoy solving them too, but the joy of having a new puzzle is so much greater than the pleasure of successfully solved one. My innate nature makes an analyst and I get immense amounts of satisfaction from that because there are always new puzzles to solve, but it's the possession of a new puzzle that is the real attraction. As to what that letter I received all those years ago actually contained, I'll leave you with your imagination. The answer will never be as good, or as bad, as the reality. And that's the point.

A normal person, when growing up, dreams of how their life will be when they are older. They dream that they will be wealthy, able to afford their every whim. But I, I did not dream that. Money meant, and still means, little to me. It powers my life, but is not essential to it. A normal person, when growing up, may dream of power, being the CEO of a corporation or the President of the United States, respected and feared by their fellow man. But I did not dream of that. Power is only a means to an end, not the end itself. A normal person, when growing up, may dream of owning precious items, cars, houses, things that would make them envied by those people around them. But I did not dream of that. Items mean little to me other than as a touchstone of my progress. A normal person dreams of love, having a husband or a wife and children who fulfill them. Love now, love I dreamt of. And as unimportant as wealth, power and things are to me, love fills the space left by them. Love was all I wanted, all I dreamt of, all I prayed for, all I wished for. As others lust after power and money, I lusted after love. I didn't want normal, plain love. I wanted someone who would be consumed by their love for me, someone for whom I would be their world. I burnt sacrifices to dark gods in search of that goal, shed blood for anyone who might answer my call. I wanted someone who could love me in ways that I could not love myself. Someone who could see inside me and find something there worth loving. The gods know that I am the most arrogant of men, one who feels their value is immeasurable. But lovable? No, I do not love myself. Or perhaps I love myself too well but share my brain with a beast. That beast knows all of my secrets, all of my hidden, dark thoughts, knows that as arrogant as I am, I am not worthy of being envied, of being respected, of being loved. Had I a true nemesis, I don't believe that they could have done a better job in destroying myself than I have done. I should place a plaque in the center of some desolate land and on it write: My name was Frederich Von Teufel. I created the greatest and most beautiful of works, achieved my life-long dream and owned the most precious items in the entire world. And when the day came, I chose to destroy those works and those items so that none shall see my works after I am gone. I had the greatest of Nemesis and he tore my life apart, down to its most infinitesimal part; my Nemesis was as great as I, for he was I. Pray that you never be so blessed. Weep, for you will never be so blessed.

I will out myself right up front. Years ago I worked for BankOne; technically I worked for a subsidiary of B1, First USA. First USA was the main division through which B1 controlled [i]all[/i] it's credit cards. Through this experience I have some hard won knowledge I can pass on. Please note that some of this is rather like knowing how sausage is made; it's disgusting and nauseating, but even with the knowledge you'll find it hard to pass up having some on you plate come Sunday morning. Chances are, if you have a credit card, that you are banking with one of only a handful of banks. In the last few decades there have been so many mergers and acquisitions that you probably don't know who the actual parent company is anymore. In my example, I dealt with approximately 3000 different credit cards (yes, that is [u]thousand[/u]) that were all handled by the same company. You may have thought that you were dealing with your local bank (Chevy Chase Bank) but Chevy Chase Banks credit cards were handled by First USA, which was owned by BankOne, which was owned by JP Morgan. JP Morgan ran all the NFL branded credit cards, the NHL credit cards, the WWF credit cards; pretty much if you had a specialty branded card, it was owned by a bank you didn't realize you were working with. Every single level one tech has access to [i]all[/i] of your records. Your name, address, mothers maiden name, your full buying history for the entire life of the card, as well as being able to pull up any other cards you may have with that bank and access that data as well. This should frighten you out of your mind, but it probably doesn't, certainly not as much as it should. Never bother trying to even fudge the truth a little bit since they have absolute access to exactly what you've done with the card and when (and how much) you've paid on it. Every single tech hates you. It's not your fault, it's the banks doing. Every tech has an absolute maximum call time they are supposed to handle every single call within. When I was working with First USA, that call time was 190 seconds. In that time I needed to greet you, ask your name, verify the credit card number and the security question on the account, remember to use the customers name throughout the rest of the call, ask what issue you were having it, confirm the issue, fix the issue, annotate the account with what I had done, ask if you were satisfied that the problem had been addressed and fixed, ask if you were having any other problems with the account (fix those if you did), and then get you off the line. I could not hang up, you had to, and until you did the call was not ended. I also needed to be pleasant and emphasize customer service. I had to be logged into the system and available to take a call 95% of the time; that's 95% of an 8 to 12 hour shift. If I failed in any of those things I got punished. If my average call time for the quarter was over 190 seconds, I got fired. For my two year working with the bank, my average call time was 165 seconds or less. For that I got a pat on the head and told I could continue to make an incredibly crappy wage working with people I hated, talking with customers I hated, for the absolute minimum time I could get away with. Customers, it wasn't your fault that I did the absolute minimum I could for you, that was the job description. That was how the bank wanted it. The banks want you to never be able to pay off your cards. They hate people who never have a revolving balance. Banks make money because of the interest, because you are late making payments, because your life is going to shit and you are drowning in debt. That's where they live. They love people who want to do balance transfers from another credit card, and they are not upset when you threaten to cancel your card. When a bank has 100 million customers, a single $10,000 account means nothing to them. And when a customer can't pay on a credit card debt? Meaningless to them. They won't lose a dime. Here's how: While you aren't paying, they are adding money to the debt. If, after 6 months or a year, you still don't pay, they sell that debt to a collection agency, take the money they were paid by the agency and write off the remainder as a bad debt on their taxes. Do the math, the bank hasn't lost a dime; actually, due to the way debt is handled, being able to write it off on their taxes actually results in a profit for them. Please note that at this point YOU still owe money that the bank has already written off and made a profit off. The collection agencies then hound you for years trying to get you to put even a single payment to the debt. If you do, it counts as if you've reaffirmed the debt and any time limit on the debt is reset to that point. I'll skip over a lot of the technicalities but it's often much better to simply immediately declare bankruptcy than to allow collection agencies to trade your debt back and forth. You should never feel bad for the bank or the collection agencies; you've been the designated sucker in this game of chance and the truth is that the minute you put your money down, you lost. How to improve your handling time with a bank: Never allow yourself to get emotional. Emotion will only slow down the game. Now that you know the tech is trying to end this call as soon as possible, play ball with them. When they are doing what you want, try to help them improve their call time. Write down the techs name immediately, and use it back to them. They will be making a habit of calling you "Mister Jones", use their name right back at them; it shows them that you are aware of the game. Don't get chatty, simply state your problem, answer their questions as succinctly as possible and drive as quickly as possible towards the solution. This means that you do need to have an idea of why you are calling. "I have a charge I don't recognize on my account statement." "I have a late fee on my account." "I need to know what my available balance is." "I'd like to get my credit limit increased." (and for that last one, "also need someone to smack me in the face and ask me what the fuck I think I'm doing.") If you ever call your credit card while drunk and fuck the tech around, know that will be noted on your account for the rest of your life. If you've ever cursed out a tech, same thing. Techs take great glee in noting your every fuck up; remember they hate you because the bank wants them to hate you. All level one techs have the ability to remove a single fee off your account every year; it's also your right to ask to have one fee removed a year. If you haven't had this done, simply ask, "I see I have *suchandsuch* a fee on my account; I'd like that removed as a one time courtesy." That last part is the key phrase, memorize it. Please note that, if you have a single late fee, you've just lost whatever "introductory APR" the bank tempted you with. No, they won't give it back to you. Remember, you signed the contract for the card, you accepted all the evil plans they had for you. It's not their fault you thought you wouldn't be eaten by the sharks. You were wrong. That's how banks work. Level one techs normally don't have the power to do anything with your credit limit or your APR, and sometimes they can't do a security hold. You'll normally need to get the call escalated to have that handled. The key things for getting your call escalated in a timely manner are to allow the level one tech to get your name, account, and security verification out of the way, THEN ask to have the call escalated and give them the reason why you want it to be escalated. It's very rare a tech will fight you on this, but if they do, simply calmly ask them something along the following "I'd like to have my APR lowered. Are you able to do that? Then please escalate my call to the department which can. Thank you." Be polite, be calm, and never raise your voice. If you ever call your credit card and receive the least amount of grief, it's usually easier to immediately have the call escalated. Ask for their supervisor or manager. It's quite possible that they'll hang up on you, but all banks record all calls, and there is a great chance that doing that will come back on them. Think of it that you arr helping clean out the techs who haven't yet figured out how to play the game; yes it fucks with you, but you were already being fucked with. This way might actually have been faster. When you call back, get your call escalated immediately, and let the manager know that you were hung up on by *techs name* after you asked to have the call escalated. You did write it down, right? See? Instant karma. All of what I just passed on was distasteful, but here is the really nasty thing. If you want "good credit" so that you can buy a house or a car, you really need to have two different credit card histories of several years. There are other ways of building a credit history, but credit cards do it better and faster. Since you kind of need them, know that there is only one way to play the game. Never let a credit card balance exist for more than one month. That means you never use your credit card for anything you don't actually have the cash for. You must let the balance revolve, other wise it doesn't help your credit history, but every time you let the balance revolve, you are putting yourself deeper into a hole of shit from which you may never be able to crawl out. And even if you do, you'll still be covered in shit. Full disclosure final: I do have one credit card. It stays in a lock box. I let the balance revolve once a year. And I never consider myself safe just because I know what the game is.

Scurrilous is a Speed Metal band.

Speed Metal, in case you don't know, has one song.  The song is lent out to each band when they are recording an album, and each Speed Metal group is allowed to play the song in 10 or 12 different ways before they have to give the song back so the next group in line can have it.

Apparently this has been working out real well for the genre.

Scurrilous put out their most recent album, "Protest The Hero", on March 22nd, 2011.  This is the bands 3rd album, so you know that they have gotten pretty good at playing that song, and the album shows this.  They play the shit out of the Speed Metal song for the first four tracks and then decide to show that they are totally trying to expand their audience with the 5th track, "Tapestry".  Apparently Scurrilous has been talking with 90s Hair Metal Groups and got permission to borrow one of their songs; this is a good thing and is perhaps one of their best tracks from the albums.  I don't know what drugs they gave their drummer, but I approve.  They then go back to their roots, and the rest of album follows the established Speed Metal pattern.

My rating on the album is an 8 on the Speed Metal Scale; Rody Walker, the lead singer, neither screeches his lyrics nor does the dramatic, gravely baritone, and therefore looses some points.  His tenor range of vocals spends too much time actually being melodic; someone needs to take him aside and tell him that Speed Metal groups are only supposed to have 3 note vocals.

Scurrilous is dangerously close to losing their Speed Metal cred and being classified as *gasp* "Progressive Metal".

Heaven forfend.

"Our bodies burn red when we kiss, but every other color also develops to remind us that a kiss will eventually end in pain." I awoke to this dream message. I can tell you that it had absolutely nothing to do with the dream I had been having just moments previously, nor do I actually understand what deeper meaning the message itself may have. I'm just reporting it.

I'm not like any one else in my waking life, why should I be like other people when I sleep?

My dreams don't normally have anyone I know in them.  Quite frequently I'm not in them either.  My dreams usually involve a cast of characters that are appropriate for the story that is being told; fictional characters in a fictional world.  The stories sometimes have relevance to what's going on in my waking life, but usually the link in tenuous.  The stories themselves seem more like they've been written by someone else, as if I have a dream muse who has given me the tale.

I follow the story as if I were part of an audience rather than the participant.  I do step into the role of a character who takes my interest, sometimes changing from one character to another as the story progresses.  I do influence the course of the story as it unfolds but I normally follow a logical progression rather than reacting as my waking self.

I do have 'normal dreams' also, peopled by people I know and where my waking self takes part as a character.  I occasionally also have lucid dreams, where I balance on the knives edge between sleep and waking, and am in full control of everything that goes on.

Very rarely do I have nightmares.  The infrequent times I do, I will have a conscious realization that I'm having a nightmare and will wrench myself out of the dream.  If you've never done this to yourself, it's an incredibly disturbing feeling, akin to dragging yourself out of water when you are drowning.  The feeling is almost as bad as the nightmare itself.

I have no clever thoughts on this, no lesson to be learned.

Regret is wishing you had made different choices in your life.

I've successfully lived my life 99% regret-free.  I'd like to lie and say I live completely without regret, but I am human and there is little point in lying to myself.  It's not that I don't make mistakes or that my life has been a particularly perfect one.  I live without regret because I accept the mistakes I've made, the hurt that was done to me, and the hurt that I've done to others.  I don't excuse the mistakes or put the blame on others.  So how can I both accept my mistakes and not feel regret for them?

I disassociate the emotion from the action.  That sounds clinical and detached, and I suppose it is.  By removing the emotion you are left with the chance to analyze the intentions, the motivations, the actions themselves and not have them be colored by any bitterness, anger or sorrow.  It allows you to focus on the one immutable fact: once an action has occurred, there is no way of 'taking it back'.  You get one chance to make a decision, one opportunity to live your life.  Each choice you make both closes all the other doors to the moment and opens all the other doors to your future.

You can easily see what your past was like, where you made wrong decisions and right ones.  No one can see where our decisions will take us in the future.  To regret our past decisions is to doubt our ability to make decisions now.  Better to leap blindly into a raging river than to stand forever in the same spot.

Yet, sometimes during quiet moments I mourn for the things I've lost, the choices I made.  Sometimes I wonder what my life might have been like if I had chosen a different path.  There are no take-backs and I think that is a good thing.

Can you imagine the torture it would cause if you could?  Regret is bad enough, the actual ability to change things would be more destructive than can be imagined.  Perhaps it's better that we regret; it gives us the opportunity to learn from our mistakes and make all new ones in the future.

I've spent the last few months trying to answer a deep and compelling question. What genre of music do I prefer? Well, it's deep and compelling to me. And a bitch to answer. My tastes in music are vast, running the gambit from New Age to Dub Step, Opera to Hip Hop. My music collection would seem bizarre to any one else, I suspect. Hell, it seems bizarre to me. As diverse as my tastes are, there are still songs that 'call' to me; songs written in a minor key or songs that do a particularly good job at expressing emotion get high marks from me. But was there a genre of music I had a preference for? The first hurdle I had was figuring out what categories particular artists fell into. Some were easy, Pop or Punk are distinctive. Speed Metal is hard to mistake. Other artists tend to have styles that evolve or are diverse within an album. Also, the number of categories (and sub-categories) seems to multiply if you turn your attention away even for a moment. Looking at the artist I consider to be favorites and then cross referencing them with how they were categorized (yeah, I used wikipedia for that mostly), I tried to find a commonality. Commonality? Commonality was almost impossible to find. Industrial rock, alternative rock, industrial metal, baroque pop, electronica, piano rock, pop, house, rock, post-grunge, progressive rock, synth-pop, new wave, rap, alternative dance, alternative metal... Fortunately, 'almost impossible' isn't the same as 'impossible'. Alternative rock turned up quite a bit. The unfortunate thing is that 'alternative rock' is such a broad category that it's almost meaningless. The Smiths and Nine Inch Nails are both alt-rock; do they sound anything alike? I suppose it could be worse, 'rock' is even worse as a category. So, after months of trying to analyze my tastes, what have I learned? My tastes are simply too eclectic to categorize. I try to listen to as broad a range of music as I can because I'm never certain if I'll really like it. The new R.E.M album (Collapse Into Now) didn't do much for me, but I did like the new Radiohead (The King of Limbs). The last Linkin Park album (A Thousand Suns) simply blew me away. The Avril Lavigne album (Goodbye Lullaby) is okay, but it's missing the rawness and anger of her early stuff; it's become mainstream pop, and that's a shame. Rise Against (Endgame) was pretty good, but there wasn't anything that grabbed me on the first run through. Scurrilous (Protest The Hero) was a stream of speed metal that all sounded the same to me; there needed to be more of a range to the songs, I like a drummer who can actually play more than a single pattern, and Scurrilous can't deliver that. On an tangent point, I actually put together a mix cd earlier this week; first one I've made in years. Trying to put together a playlist of songs that you think a person would like, but that they had never heard before, is a refreshing challenge. Makes me wish that I had the opportunity to dj for a webcast; I've always thought that would be kind of fun. Me as a dj might be a little too challenging for my listeners though.

I find it incredibly odd that I don't dance. With music being such an integral part of my very being, literally being part of my life as far back as I can remember, I would expect that I would want to be able to let the music out of me in a physical way. And letting the music out is something that I do want. There's so much music inside me that it fills me up until there is no part of me that isn't steeped in it. There is so much music inside me that I should sweat musical notation. It feels odd to say that I have an innate sense of rhythm; I'm made of music, of course I can keep a beat. I think I began drumming when I lost my singing voice at puberty, but it's quite possible that I was drumming before then. I've never had any formal training, my hands have simply always known what to do. I recollect the first time I sat down at a friends full drum kit and played along with a song on the stereo; I remember instinctually keeping up with the drummer but being shocked into insensibility when my hands reached out and hit that cymbal the first time. How had my hands known when and how to do that? All that being said, I don't want to imply that I've never danced or even that I can't dance. With drumming my hands have simply known what to do, but dancing has always been about mimicry to me; I conciously watch others and steal their moves. I know I was taught how to ballroom dance in grade school. Back in the very early 80's I had a friend who was in to hip hop and he got me to be part of his crew. I was never able to do head spins, but I could pop, lock and crazy-legs well enough. I've gone out to clubs, danced at my prom, danced at weddings, danced at parties. But when I'm alone, I don't dance. The one time when I don't have to be concerned with any one watching, worry about anything more than letting the music move me in an instinctual way, I don't dance. If there is anything about myself that disappoints me, it's this. Some years ago I was at an SCA event that was predominantly a teaching event. During lunch time I was in the eating area chatting with an acquaintance; in the open space right next to my table there was a group of people doing medieval dance. One of the ubiquitous things about medieval dance is that it rarely has an even distribution of men to women; women usually outnumber the men greatly. This makes things difficult because almost all of the dances are partner dances; dancing was a significant means of interaction among men and women historically, it was one of the few ways that was socially acceptable to get close to one another in a public forum. Medieval dance is essentially ritualized flirting. In other word, it was exactly what dance is today. I'm good at flirting and, when I want to wear the mask of charm, I feel comfortable doing so. I've never needed dancing as a way of expressing myself to a partner. Watching others at play is amusing though, so I had been casually glancing at the dancers while talking with my friend. "Excuse me." I turned to find a very attractive woman, one of the dancers, had approached me. "Will you come be my partner in this dance?" My knee-jerk reaction was surprise and a powerful feeling of reluctance. "Actually, I-" I paused. Didn't particularly feel like dancing? Didn't know the dance steps to whatever song was going to be next? Didn't want to break off the conversation I'd been having? All true. And all stupid reasons. Was there any good reason why I wouldn't want to bring some happiness to this particularly cute girl? I smiled at her warmly. "-I can't think of anything that I'd rather be doing." I took her hand and led her out to the dance floor. I should remind myself of that story more often...

Why does Myth have such power over me? Myth is history, tales told to remember what has gone before so that those things never fade from our minds. History, as it's taught normally, is about dates and names but Myth takes those facts and elevates them, humanizes them, brings the listener closer to the people who we find in those tales. I tell tales to ensure that the times I felt were important to me are held forever. It's a mnemonic in a way, a method by which I fix these stories in to my own memory. Sometimes I allow the story to be improved to tell a better tale; I remember the truth of the story even if no one else does. I've done this for a long time; storytelling, I mean. I think we all do, although I do have doubts about that at times. Our own lives are stories we tell to ourselves; our motivations, our feelings, our thoughts on the motivations and feelings of others. How could we ever tell what's really going on in other people's heads? Bereft of that knowledge we are left to create our own realities for ourselves. Back in 1991, fresh from University and back in the state of Maryland, I asked a friend of mine for help in integrating myself into the scene. She suggested going to a small sci-fi con called Disclave. It's a "relax-i-con" she said. Even though it was a small con, it had a hugely diverse group of attendees. Once she offered crash space in her hotel room, which she was sharing with two other friends, I was sold. "I can't offer more than a spot on the floor," she said. I just smiled and nodded; I was just happy for the help. After the weekend I came home and wrote the following as a desperate brain dump in hopes of remembering all the details. It's been almost 20 years since that con, but this morning I finally came across the notebook and am finally able to archive the story. *** Monday 11:45 pm, May 27th, 1991 What do I feel? An intriguing question. I'm a little sad. A little happy. And there's a small part of me that is wishing that my life could always be like this. The 1991 Disclave is over. My first real con. An enlightening experience. I hardly know where to start there's so much. 1st, my mentor. Lise K. Middle name Kassandra. Roll that middle name around, it tells you much about that person. I couldn't say she is attractive, although she is. Charismatic? She has enough for five people. Beautiful? That and so much more. So what can I say she is? My friend. Masturbating her to see the look of pleasure and happiness ("Why the fuck are you up this early?" "I have no fucking idea.") Cuddling with her. Dancing. Being introduced to people (Joe and Jay Haldeman, Barchan (jousting man), Cindy?Sandra? (coffee skin and honey hair), and a thousand others (Albion). Talking with her in the 'cuzzi (the painful secret, sex, love, crying), going to the cabanas around the pool (Pan Galactic Gargleblasters, dancing, chocolate fondue, drunk people, being envious of people's costumes, Dave the male-lesbian in drag), talking, showering in the morning, trying to wake her. Friends. FL. Jennifer (Allcott?) The tickling, playing cards, pillow fighting, foot/back/body massages, black lace teddy w/black cloak, depressed over Dan's self-hurt, agreeing to bisexuality and self-congratulations for not drinking, hugs and kisses, distant & cold (did I do something wrong? You say no but I feel yes.) Nudity. Albion/me/FL/Lise. Lise/FL/me in hot tub. Changing clothes. Lazing around. Being allowed in bed first and second night. Eating out at the Bob's Big Boy. Eating in (strawberry & kiwi breakfast, strawberries to die for, Pringles and pickles, ham sandwich.) Kissing. Back rub from Albion. Hi-low cards. Strip poker in reverse. Elevator being stuck and refusing to move. Sitting as Buddha. Captain Speedo. Hug from woman (Gilda? Glynis?) Close dancing with FL. My tickle spots, FL ticklish everywhere. Talking with Lise and T-shirt Guy about civilization and government and solving everything and nothing. Mundanes. Party in the Second Circle of Hell as Monsieur le Viscount de Valmont with Maid Marion (why else were the merry men merry?), Lilith, Cherub, Only Beer, Sir Lawrence Olivier (Haldemann), Satan and the see-everything-thru stockings. Albion's oil, hair pins for Lise, video tapes (Anime!), and Olivia prints in the Huckster's Room. FL's necklace (grandfathers'). Wearing the white cloak. Trust. There, everything out, empty, no more. Except for one thing. Happiness. "Don't bother me with reality, I'm too busy being arrogant." "Of course I'm arrogant, the best usually are." "When everything is outlawed, the outlaws will have everything." "Don't let your mind wander. Something that small shouldn't be out alone." *** I'm sad to say that there are a couple things in there that even I can't remember exactly what it's referring to. However, there was so much more that refreshed the memory of that weekend; it doesn't feel like it was 20 years ago, not that it did before I found the notebook. If I look back on all the years between that weekend and today, I can see the vastness of the story that lay at my feet. FL went on to be my SO for 7 years and she stood as my Best Man at my wedding. We are still acquaintances today. Lise and I lost touch after 4 or 5 years; I saw her through her wedding and divorce, Hawaii, and a career in phone-sex and dancing. I love her as much now as I did back then; I hope she remembers me as fondly wherever she is in the world. The person I am today is not really that different than the man I was then. All the things I've done and seen and experienced haven't really changed me. I know and understand so much more now because of those experiences, yet the path between who I am and who I was is indelible and obvious. I still see no further into the future now than I did in 1991. The plot of my story is still waiting for me to tread upon it unknowingly and fearfully. All of my history is precious to me; I treasure my Myth. It's what's made me into who I am today and I like myself. I accept my flaws and my pains. I accept what my future might be and hope that the climax of my story is a good one. The tale has been great so far.

I've spoken in the past quite a lot regarding dominance and submission rituals amoung humans. I've been aware of these things since I was a kid; I deliberately practiced these rituals, working out how people react, and how to manipulate the results. And yet I am continually suprised when a psych journal will publish something like this, Staring Establishes Dominance, as if it's brand new research. This is still news to people? Hell, anyone can try this just walking down a street: meet any person's eyes as they are passing you; within 3 seconds they will break eye contact. Most people won't be able to hold eye contact for even that long. I knew about this when I was barely into my teens. I'll admit that my epiphany came via the works of the great primatoligists, Jane Goodall, Franz de Waal, Dian Fossey, and Desmond Morris, but it isn't like their work hasn't been around for decades. More startling new revelations: Humans are animals, Society is about power and there is no sanctity of human life. Oh yes, and the most surprising new revelation is my disgust that people will reject the previous three declarations. Pardon me while I and my sarcasm go drink in a corner alone...

Using a urinal, as a male, is an act of dominance and submission. Very early on you are taught as to which urinals you are 'allowed' to use, but you are never taught why. Women, I am certain, have similar D/S rituals, but I doubt that you undergo a ritual that is as nuanced as this one. The best way I can explain this is to walk you through it. Here you will find an ideal example of a set of male urinals. Let me ask you a series of questions. Don't think about these questions, just react on an instinctual basis to them. 1) You walk in to an empty bathroom and have your choice of urinals. Which do you choose? That one should be pretty easy, so let's make these next couple more difficult. 2) You walk in to this bathroom to find a person using urinal A. Which do you choose? 3) You walk into this bathroom to find a person using urinal B. Which do you choose? 4) You walk into this bathroom to find a person using urinal C. Which do you choose? 5) Finally, you walk in to this bathroom to find a person using urinal D. Which do you choose? Now, we'll finish with a harder set of questions. 6) You walk in to this bathroom to find a person using urinal A and B. Which do you use? 7) You walk in to this bathroom to find a person using urinal A and C. Which do you use? 8) You walk in to this bathroom to find a person using A and D. Which do you use? Now, the hardest two questions: 9) You walk into this bathroom and find a person using urinals A, B, and C. What do you do? 10) You walk into this bathroom and find a person using urinals A, C and D. What do you do? If you are wondering if there is an "answer key" for the 10 questions asked above, the answer is yes, there is. But there is no "correct answer" for those questions, just the answers that you gave. Human beings act out subconscious dominance and submission rituals every day. The reason for this is that they are naturally trying to find their place within the pack structure. Humans gravitate towards one of three roles: the Alpha, the Beta, and the Omega. In the above example, the urinals are the natural congregation point for males to demonstrate their place in the pack structure. The urinal marked A and C are Beta urinals (I will return to the nuance of the C urinal in a moment.) The urinal marked B is clearly the Alpha urinal as it exerts the most influence over the urinals around it. The urinal marked D is also clearly the Omega urinal; it's at a lower level than the others and is placed against a protective wall. The reason that the C urinal is a Beta urinal is that it exerts its influence over the Omega urinal; it could be said that it's the Beta urinal with hopes of moving up the pack ladder. The A urinal is a solid Beta due to it being protected by the wall on one side and being under the influence of the Alpha urinal on the other side. So, if you predominantly chose one urinal over another, you subconscious was telling you how you feel about your place in the pack. You can consciously make the choice to change this; it is possible for an Omega to become the Alpha of a pack, Franz de Waal has an excellent example of how this is done in his book, "Chimpanzee Politics".

I was a skater boy. That's a secret I've kept for about 30 years. I was introduced to a skateboard in '76 if I recollect. Skating was a very different thing back then, it was all about freestyle and ramps were talked about, but rarely seen. Boards were so much narrower, still showed huge influence from the surfing scene and were...well, primitive. But there was a skate shop near my school and it was an awesome place to hang out. If there is any reason I can give for why I got into skating, it was because the scene gave me place to belong. There was also a huge creative aspect to skating; not just in the skating, but also in all the ways you could customize your board and wheels. It was all a way of expressing yourself. This isn't to say it was all positive. Being a long-haired skater boy in Maryland in the late '70s was no more accepted than...well, than Maryland has ever accepted long-haired skater boys. I took the opportunity when I moved to a new High School to reinvent myself; it's one of those things that people rarely have the chance to do and even more infrequently take advantage of. My impetus was that there simply was no skate culture at the new High School. I have wondered what I might have done if there had been a group I could have easily slipped into. I put away my board, tried various hair styles and clothes, even dabbled in everything from prep to hip hop. We emulate the look of the social group we are trying to be part of; it's basic camoflage. This was the point in my life where I formalized my understanding of masks and costume, how to manipulate and influence others in non-vocal ways. I'm not unhappy I left that skater boy behind. The fact that I never regret any of the choices I've made in my life is a product of having made the choices I did. The skater boy I was wouldn't have understood that, but the man I've become does.

There is a bulletin board I've been a member of for more than 13 years now; I was actually a member of the BB's predecessor too. Over the years the BB has gone from having 3 or 4 topic sections to having around 2 dozen. Like most BBs the majority of those sections are targeted to the specific interests of the board and for many years there was only one other section for "other stuff", the ubiquitous "Off-Topic" section. A number of years ago, due to the savage arguments that would start in the OT board, they split off a "Politics" board and the mods have been very diligent in ensuring that anything 'political' lived and stayed in that area. I'm given to understand that the Politics board can be pretty wild and that there are few restrictions, although if the meat of your argument lays in name-calling you get ignored by the other members pretty quickly. I say that 'I'm given to understand' because I've never visited that section myself. I have zero desire to. This does seem strange to me, because there was a time in my life where I actually enjoyed a good argument. The passionate sharing of ideas and beliefs did hold an attraction for me. That attraction is long gone. Usenet newsgroups still exist today, although I wonder just how many people are aware of their existence. I come from a time where newsgroups were the height of internet communications. Before AOL and Compuserve, there were things like FidoNET where you directly dialed in to a local BBS that hooked you into the network of other computer servers, all sharing information packets back and forth. Before AIM, Facebook, and Twitter, I remember spending my nights on IRC talking peer-to-peer with people all over the world. And, boy, did I enjoy a good argument. Exchanging ideas, encountering culture clashes, crafting logical arguments to prove your point and disprove the argument of your counterpart; it was satisfying. Right up until the point where I realized I was making the same case for the hundredth time. Had I swayed anyone to my side of the argument, had I changed anyone's opinion? Not that I could tell. It would be fair to say that the arguments I engaged in helped me to catalyze my own opinions, my own beliefs, but then I am an analyst by nature and I use everything in my life to analyze and reanalyze my beliefs. Perhaps I stopped arguing not because I stopped believing that the arguments could help make myself better, but because I stopped believing that my arguments were making anyone else better. Or perhaps I just got more subtle. I still share my opinions and beliefs, but I now do it in forums where I'm teaching, where my opinion has value to the person that's hearing it. Conflict was never the thing I looked for, and it's the thing I am most happy to leave behind.

I've been trying to tell a particular story in my head. Coming up with ideas has never been a problem for me, if anything I've always worked to reject that multiplicity. I would much rather have a few, perfect, stories than to have a million stories that are crap. It has left me with the main issue in that I never truly think any of my stories are finished. I have one particular story that I have told perhaps a hundred times now for audiences; while I do take pride in that I've, deliberately, never told the story the exact same way twice, much of that motivation also comes from trying to constantly improve the story. So, I've been tortured by the particular "new" story I have, but I've seen some unexpected results from trying new ways of getting at this story. The story itself is really irrelevant and I won't bother to go into details; it's normal human drama of love, loss, motivations and life. The only thing I've added to this story is a filter through which the story is told. Well, maybe I'm doing myself a disservice; I know that the basics of this story have never been told, and I know it's certainly never been told via the tropes I'm using. Human beings will always be what they are, motivated by the same basics; what matters is the how the story is told. I quickly sketched in the framework of the story, the main characters, their backgrounds and motivations, and I can absolutely say that I've never had as easy a time of it as I've had with this one. All due to using my webcam as a video diary; I poured out more than 3 hours of focused stream of conciousness. That was 3+ hours of recorded video, mind you. I'm not certain how long it took me IRL. Compared to what that would have taken me to write down, however, it was a huge time saver. It allowed me to get the skeleton done and out of the way and on to considering how to actually make this story interesting. And that was a major question for me, because I quickly realized that how I had originally envisioned telling the story, while having great potential, also had great problems. People don't like dramas. Well, they do; dramas all gather the greatest respect, but really the larger audience prefers comedies. Hell, I like comedies. Humor is always an important part of my stories if I can find a way to add it in; people remember comedy better than they remember drama. So, the fact that the heart of my story was about the boundaries of negative emotion makes it difficult to involve a light-hearted tone. Answer: Absurdity. You must balance emotion with it's opposite extreme. (I'll ignore exactly how I can do that because I only have that partially answered for the moment.) The wall I've been beating my head against for the last couple of days is how to get around simply having the main character tell the story from their viewpoint (essentially making the viewer, via the camera, a character in the story.) There is a reason why you don't see many films take this approach. It's because it sucks. You need interaction. This is why buddy films work; there are two characters who can interact and further the story in a natural way. So I need to add one more character to my little story. As soon as I realized what I need to do, I knew who the character needed to be; it was as if once I acknowledged the need for his existence he stepped through the door where he'd been waiting just outside. I haven't convinced him to submit to my concept of the story yet; he has strong feelings about things, drama that hadn't existed while he was off-screen except by allusion, now that drama is right up front and needs to be dealt with (which is killing my humor-flow at the moment.) In one hand, it's exciting; I've done more deep analysis of a story, in a startlingly short time, than I have ever done before, but I'm really no closer to answering the one question regarding this story that I've had from the instant it was conceived. I don't know how it ends. Well, let me be more clear, I know lots of ways that I could end this story, but I don't know how this story should be ended. I'm content to let that question remain unanswered for now. Perhaps I should move on to diagraming this movie, working on timelines and other background information while still letting the problem of how to tell the story percolate away in my brain. I still need to sit down and video diary a entry for the new character to this Dramedy.

No matter how many, or what, mistakes we make or how carefully we try to learn from them, there are always more that we make.

Mistakes are that magical creature that we don't recognize until we are right up on them and frequently not until they are well past.

Many years ago, while I was in University, I had a group of friends who were very much in to anime.  Back then to be an otaku you had to have friends who lived in japan (or were friends of friends) who would pass you a copy of an anime via mail.  Most commonly the tape was a copy of a copy of a copy...but since there was no other recourse to seeing some of these anime you were happy with what you got.

One day one of our group broke the news that he'd been able to get a copy of the film "Akira", and that the copy was merely a 2nd generation or so, making it very watchable.  We all met that night, gathered around the VCR with beer and snacks in hand to gaze upon the wonder that was a ground breaking anime.  Filmed in 60 fps, loads of violence and adult themes.  We were awe-struck.

I should pause here to mention that most of the anime we obtained this was was still in the original japanese.  There was no dubbing, no subtitles.  This was okay though, since many of us were taking japanese classes, and "Akira" is fairly easy to follow even if you don't understand what is being said.

Easy to follow, that is, right up until the last 5 minutes or so.  The last part of the film doesn't have much dialog, and what there was didn't make much sense.

For weeks afterwards the group of us would get together and discuss what we thought the ending of "Akira" meant.  We argued.  We came up with theories.  We racked our brains and eventually came up with the theory that the reason we didn't understand the ending was due to cultural differences; if we were japanese and had grown up there it would make more sense to us.

Fast forward to several months later.  Another member of the group and I were in the local big comic book store when a japanese gentleman, middle aged and dressed in a suit, came in to the store to buy comics.  We struck up a conversation and it turned out that this gentleman was visiting from japan and was taking the opportunity to buy many of the comic books that he couldn't get back home.  We mentioned that we were part of an anime fan group and began talking about the various films we'd seen.  We asked if he'd seen "Akira".

"Yes, I have," said the man.

My friend and I exchanged wide-eyed significant looks.  We explained to the man that we'd only seen the film in japanese and that we hadn't really understood the ending of the film.  Did he think he could explain it to us?

"Ah.  Well, you must understand that I've grown up reading manga and watching anime my whole life,"  he said.  "I don't understand the ending of 'Akira' either."

And just like that, my friend and I were enlightened.
